#Repost @pacegallery „Éª„Éª„Éª
Pace is pleased to present 'The Chronicles of San Francisco - Sketches,' an exhibition of new work by French artist and photographer JR (@jr), on view at Pace‚Äôs gallery in Palo Alto from February 6 ‚Äì March 24, 2019. Encompassing portraits, works on paper, video installations, lightboxes, and etched glass works, the exhibition is derived from and inspired by JR's upcoming monumental mural project 'The Chronicles of San Francisco,' opening at SFMOMA (@SFMOMA) in Spring 2019.
-
Known for his large-scale urban works that address socio-economic and political issues, JR created the new series in honor of the city and people of #SanFrancisco. The city‚Äôs long muralist tradition and its stark contrasts‚Äîfeaturing both immense innovation and wealth as well as one of the country‚Äôs highest rates of child homelessness‚Äîhas made it a vibrant and complex site for the artist to explore and capture. Over the course of the project, nearly 1,200 people were filmed, photographed and interviewed; each person choosing the way they were to be represented in the mural.
-
‚ÄúIn a painting, it‚Äôs usually the perspective that focuses the attention of the viewer. With this new mural technique, we break the perspective: Every person is presented at the same size, captured with the same light. No one is more important than another. It is not a group photo, but rather a group of photos...The mural aims to be a picture of society, not depicting good and bad, but rather showing that both sides are present in everyone.‚Äù‚Äî#JR
-
Image: JR, 'The Chronicles of San Francisco,' 2018, detail ¬©Ô∏è JR 2018

We‚Äôre having a #ThrowbackThursday moment, looking at some rocket-related items that have been discovered by our officers. These items were found between 2018 and 2019 at Evansville Regional Airport (EVV), Orlando International Airport (MCO), San Francisco International Airport (SFO), Sacramento International Airport (SMF), and Destin-Fort Walton Beach Airport (VPS).

Anytime we find a potential explosive device, we call in an explosive specialist to take a closer look. That process takes time and slows down the line. While today‚Äôs post is sponsored by the letter ‚ÄúF‚Äù, were going to talk about the novelty bomb that‚Äôs attached to it.
...
Yes, it‚Äôs a novelty bomb, but as we‚Äôve discussed here before, replicas of weapons, especially bombs, are not permitted in carry-on or checked bags.
...
When our officers spot a potential explosive on the monitor, they cannot just open the bag and take a looksee to find out if it‚Äôs real or not. A TSA explosives specialist or a police department bomb squad must respond before the bag is ever opened. This can lead to costly evacuations, delays, and missed flights. These types of items can also lead to hefty fines and arrest. Contact your preferred shipper about your options, because they can‚Äôt travel via commercial aircraft. So even though they aren‚Äôt real, they can cause a lot of very real headaches.
...
As for the ‚ÄúF‚Äù, after long and careful thought, we‚Äôve determined that it must stand for Fred. This must have been Fred‚Äôs novelty bomb. It was discovered in a carry-on bag at the Salt Lake City International Airport (SLC).

In the novel The Call of the Wild, a dog named Buck is stolen from his home and sold as a sled dog in Alaska, where he must learn to survive the harsh winter conditions. This knife, discovered at the security checkpoint at Central Nebraska Regional Airport (GRI), could inspire one to take a similar journey into the wilderness. ‚Ä¶
If you are packing for your own Yukon trek, please remember to remove all knives from your carry-on luggage. While knives may not be carried through the security checkpoint (except for plastic or round bladed butter knives), they may be packed in checked bags.

Are we cool? We like to think we‚Äôre cool. We want you to have a pleasant experience at the airport and arrive safely at your destination. But getting caught while trying to fly with marijuana or cannabis-infused products can really harsh your mellow.
Let us be blunt: TSA officers DO NOT search for marijuana or other illegal drugs. Our screening procedures are focused on security and detecting potential threats. But in the event a substance appears to be marijuana or a cannabis infused product, we‚Äôre required by federal law to notify law enforcement. This includes items that are used for medicinal purposes.

If you‚Äôre bringing your pet through the security checkpoint for a flight, please don‚Äôt send them through that dark x-ray tunnel! Instead, place their empty carrier on the belt, then walk or carry them through the scanner. ‚Ä¶

Finally, don‚Äôt forget to check with your air carrier. Policies for traveling with pets can vary from airline to airline. ‚Ä¶

No matter the size, shape or intended use, knives are prohibited from being packed in your carry-on luggage. If you do have a knife that you'd like to bring along on your next trip, make sure you place it in your checked luggage. Otherwise, leave it behind. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

Working dogs have long been an important part of life in arctic areas. Early canines served as hunting partners, camp protectors, and sled pullers. In fact, sled dogs have been in use for over 1,000 years, and they continue to be used in rural parts of Alaska, Canada and Greenland.
‚Ä¶
Carrying on that historic tradition are this playful pair, Messi-Masi (left) and Jjackman. These modern working dogs are explosive detection canines at Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport (ANC) where they help keep airline passengers safe.
‚Ä¶
Since 2001, TSA has trained explosives detection canine teams to operate in the aviation, multimodal, mass transit, and cargo environments. Once trained, these teams can quickly locate and identify dangerous materials that may present a threat to transportation systems.
‚Ä¶

The phrase 'bone of contention' refers to the main issue of a disagreement between two or more parties. The amateur etymologists here tell us that the expression originated in the 1700s and alludes to two dogs fighting over a single bone. Similarly, when one 'has a bone to pick' with another, they are referring to a grievance or issue that needs to be resolved. A passenger recently reached out to our AskTSA team to preemptively resolve a bone-related matter, specifically whether an elk pelvis bone was allowed in their luggage. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Fortunately for this traveler, animal bones can be packed as you choose, as they are allowed in both carry-on and checked luggage. We do recommend that travelers check with their airline, as some carriers may not allow a literal 'bag of bones' on their aircraft. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
If you have questions on traveling with other unusual items, reach out to our #AskTSA team on Twitter or Facebook. You can write them a message or send a photo. They're available 8am-10pm on weekdays, and 9am-7pm on weekends and holidays! ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

In 2018, a record-setting 4,239 firearms were discovered in carry-on bags across the country. 86% of those firearms discovered were loaded (also a record).
‚Ä¶
When a firearm is discovered by TSA officers at a checkpoint, it's immediately reported to law enforcement. And while firearm possession laws vary by location, TSA may impose civil penalties of up to $13,333 per incident.
‚Ä¶
If you plan to travel with a firearm, make sure you know the rules. Visit our website to find out how to properly pack the firearm with your checked luggage. You should also contact your airline for their specific policies, as well as knowing the local laws for firearms at your destination.
‚Ä¶

Doughnuts have a long and interesting history. Their origins can be traced back to the olykoek (or 'oily cakes') that Dutch settlers brought with them to New York in the 1600s. If you are a fan of auto racing, then this might be the most significant Sunday of the year. Three major races will take place today: the #MonacoGrandPrix, the #Indy500 and the #CocaCola600. Drivers and the race teams will push their machines to the limit in pursuit of the coveted checkered flag.

If you‚Äôre a racer, mechanic, or simply someone who enjoys turning wrenches, you might be planning to travel with some mechanical bits. You‚Äôll be happy to hear that car parts are allowed in carry-on or checked bags, so long as they are free of chemicals (such as gasoline, oil, and brake fluid). One important exception: parts that contain compressed gas, like shock absorbers and airbag assemblies. These parts are prohibited from being packed in both carry-on and checked luggage.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

Pumpkin pie... it's an essential item for many a Thanksgiving feast. And if you are packing for your holiday flight, you might be debating how to handle canned items, such as pie filling and cranberry sauce. Fear not... we've got an answer.
-
Most canned food items either contain liquid (think green beans for that casserole), or they have a gel (looking at you, cranberry sauce) or creamy consistency (such as that pumpkin pie filling). That means you'll need to stuff them in your checked luggage. -
So please don't put canned items in your carry-on bag. We don't want your goose to be cooked when you arrive sans ingredients!
-
And if you've got questions on other food items, reach out to our #AskTSA team on Twitter or Facebook. You can write them a message or send a photo. They're available 8am-10pm on weekdays, and 9am-7pm on weekends and holidays... even on Thanksgiving Day!
-
-
-
#travel #traveling #traveler #airport #traveltips #tsatraveltips

Valentine's Day is a wonderful time to remind that special someone how you feel. A romantic card is a lovely thought, as are flowers and candy. Or perhaps jewelry is a more appropriate sign of your strong affection.
‚Ä¶
Alternatively, you could take a lesson from a passenger at Colorado Springs Airport (COS) and give your sweetheart a big ol' bag of martial arts weapons! This carry-on goody bag, presented to our TSA officers at the security checkpoint, included an ax, throwing star, double-edged dagger, and machete. Safe travels, you romantic fool!
‚Ä¶

& here it is: book number 1,2,3,fo,FiF!!‚Äù My first cookbook (drumroll please!) #MixtapePotluck

I mixed together my passion for music & food by bringing together over 50 of my pals‚Äì a mix of chefs, entertainers, artists, thought leaders & musicians ‚Äì for the ultimate potluck party. They brought the recipes. I brought the music by pairing each personality with what I think best reflects them. Together we vibe with good food and music and highlight the beautiful synergies between the two. Special s/o to @MarthaStewart for the foreword, you could say she knows a little something about potlucks üôÉüôÉüôÉ Photography by @marcus.xoxo. Cover by @baronvonfancy and @jeanette_birdy. Out on Oct. 15th via @abramsbooks. Pre-order your copy today where books are sold. Link in Bio. #QuestLovesFood

Tonight after the @amcthewalkingdead (& @amctalkingdead) season premiere‚Äî-comes the premiere of @SongsThatShook a docuseries breaking down the creative process and science of some of our most debated/favorite/underrated/elated/hated music: Hip Hop. Season One brings us @queenlatifah & @darealmonielove‚Äôs #LadiesFirst, @rundmc‚Äôs #RockBox, @outkast‚Äôs #Elevators, @kendricklamar‚Äôs #Alright, @mcshan1 & @marleyskills #TheBridge & tonight‚Äôs pilot episode #KanyeWest‚Äôs #JesusWalks‚ÄîI‚Äôll be live tweeting tonight. Please join me (also dvr it) and let let let your friends and family and fellow hip hop heads know that we need support (the hashtag is #SongsThatShook). Questlove‚Äôs special guest at this Sunday‚Äôs Midsummer Night Conversations on Creativity is Mark Ronson! Get your tickets now at guildhall.org/questlove
Mark Ronson is an internationally renowned DJ and Academy-Award-winning, seven-time-Grammy-Award-winning and Golden Globe-winning artist and producer. He has worked on a multi Grammy-winning album by Amy Winehouse, as well as his own Grammy-winning, global smash hit with Bruno Mars, 'Uptown Funk.' Along with releasing four successful albums under his own name, his resume includes production work for some of music‚Äôs biggest names, including Adele, Paul McCartney, Duran Duran, and Lily Allen. More recently, he helmed Lady Gaga‚Äôs acclaimed fifth album, Joanne and Queens Of The Stone Age‚Äôs lauded Villains. In 2018 he released a string of singles with Diplo under the name Silk City, including the current worldwide hit ‚ÄúElectricity‚Äù with Dua Lipa, which earned him a Grammy Award for ‚ÄúBest Dance Recording‚Äù in 2019.He is a co-writer of the song ‚ÄúShallow,‚Äù recorded by Lady Gaga and Bradley Cooper for the movie A Star Is Born, for which he earned an Academy Award for ‚ÄúBest Original Song,‚Äù a Golden Globe Award for ‚ÄúBest Song Written for a Motion Picture,‚Äù a Grammy Award for ‚ÄúBest Song Written for Visual Media,‚Äù and a Grammy nomination for ‚ÄúSong of the Year.‚ÄùMost recently Mark collaborated with Miley Cyrus on the hit song, ‚ÄúNothing Breaks Like A Heart,‚Äù Lykke Li on ‚ÄúLate Night Feelings,‚Äù Camila Cabello on ‚ÄúFind U Again‚Äù and more, for his fifth studio album Late Night Feelings, which was released in June. He is currently based in Los Angeles where he operates his record label, Zelig Records, home to fast rising star King Princess. To date, Ronson has 1 Academy Award, 7 Grammy Awards, 2 Brit Awards, 1 Golden Globe Award, and 1 MTV VMA Award to his name.

John Witherspoon resonated with every last one of us because he represented someone in our family: embarrassing us at gatherings (Boomerang), misrepresenting our generations heroes (‚ÄúPublic Enema‚Äù?!), making a jingle about pretty much everything (Grandpa on Boondocks), the neighborhood wino (black Jesus‚Äî-or better yet Hollywood Shuffle)‚Äî-the list is endless. Bar none my favorite working/blue collar actor. Prolly THE most famous iconic character actor (I mean he didn‚Äôt star in vehicles but he was no doubt THE go to support) the best knew to get the best. When interviewing @davidalangrier on @QLS him describing what should have been a routine 15 min scene at the family table in Boomerang wound up being a non stop hour and a half us master class riffing amongst masters, with Witherspoon leading the way. History should tell it well, all the greats utilized him on their project for the last 45 years (Richard Pryor Show/Whats Happening!/Good Times/WKRP/227/Martin/Amen/Fresh Prince/Wayans Bros/Living Single/Boondocks/First Family/blackish/Black Jesus)‚Äî-he will forever be our pop pops. RIP

Someone I can have an entire subliminal conversation with in any environment. A scene partner of dreams. A fellow scarf-knitting grandma. The last post about the climate march ruffled some feathers. As a photojournalist, I have become increasingly aware of how my travel impacts the environment, and I do everything necessary to offset my footprint. This year I took one of my first vacations, in many years, to Mexico, where I experienced a sustainable hospitality model. Tomorrow, I'm on my way back to research, explore, photograph and report on what makes a sustainable hospitality model work. I'll be traveling to the delicate ecosystem that has been ravaged by tourisim: #Tulum, #Mexico. Stay tuned for more stories from the field as I dive deep into what makes hospitality entreprenuers, communities and travelers unite for a common good.

In the mean time, I want to know your questions, concerns, thoughts feelings about travel and tourism. Comment below!
Pictured here: freediving spear fisherman in Bajo. Captured #onassignment

#adventure #travel #culture #tourisim

Some recent conversations have brought my memories to float back in time to my first story for #NatGeo. The ‚ÄúSky Caves of Mustang‚Äù are a large collection of 10,000 or more man-made caves dug into the sides of a valley in northern #Nepal. Archeologists and researchers have explored a fraction of these caves and have found mummified human remains dating to at least 2,000-3,000 years old. .
As the world becomes smaller, exploration and discovery shifts and changes in meaning as well. Archeologists on our expedition required the support of climbers, like myself and @mattsegal, to access these caves. Just as the printing press changed history, advent of digital dissemination of not just the written word, but visual stories have altered the way we connect, research, explore and communicate. How do you feel discovery, exploration and science has changed through new world of Instagram? .
Pictured here: a cave illuminated with researchers' lamps while exploring the sky caves of Mustang.
#mustang #exploration #discovery #adventure

I bid Kuala Lumpur farewell and am on to the next leg of the journey: Mustang, Nepal.

Here's an image from my archives from my first story for @natgeo covering the Sky Caves of Mustang. A 10 year old digital file and a young eye... Much has changed, I have changed... though my heart is still there.

More soon from the road! Excited to share along the way.

#onassignment #Nepal #travel #culture

Legendary @danwintersphoto and the lightbulb ever present over his head... amazing group of people and a deep well of knowledge here at @ipfo.ch
#portrait #blackandwhite #switzerland

Some have been asking if we are on assignment for #natgeo in Mustang, Nepal to continue examining the sky Caves, a story from almost 10 years ago. This assignment we are shifting from the past to the present. The team and I are documenting how traditional practices and ways of living are adapting to the intrusion of modernity. Buddhism, roads, connectivity, migration, monarchies, climate change and tourism all place new pressures upon these ancient cultures while offering new opportunities.
.

Just like climbing, projects like these are a team effort. @jetbutterflies @abovethecloudstrav @standtallest @climber.abiral are on the ground with me, and I‚Äôm grateful for all the ways they contribute, support and continually sculpt the vision into a reality in an effort to give life to a story that must be seen by the global community.
.
Pictured here: A monk in a Mustang monastery performs a #puja, or an act of worship, in 2010 from my assignment with @natgeo magazine exploring the archeological mysteries of Mustang, Nepal.
#archeology #journalism #photojournalism #culture #travel #tourism #portrait #nepal

Changpa Nomad, Ladakh 2018. The Changpa are a semi-nomadic Tibetan people found mainly in the Changtang in Ladakh and in Jammu and Kashmir. A smaller number resides in the western regions of the Tibet Autonomous Region and were partially relocated for the establishment of the Changtang Nature Reserve. // shot using a single B1 light with a collapsible beauty dish.
#travel #portrait #culture #natgeo #india #nomad

As we start our assignment for #natgeo in Nepal, it's common to come across Mani Stones. Mani stones are plates or rocks inscribed with the 6 syllables Tibetan Buddhist mantra 'Om Mani Padme Hum'. They can be found everywhere--from the sides of roads and rivers to the walls of temples. Carving these stones can also be a devotional practice, or 'sadhana'.
.
There are many translations of this mantra, and @dalailama says 'The six syllables..can transform your impure body, speech, and mind into the pure body, speech and mind of the Buddha... All beings naturally have Buddha nature... We have within us the seed of purity, the Buddha-Essence, that can be transformed and fully developed.'
.
Pictured here: Mani Stones on my way to #everest in 2012 with @conrad_anker @hilareenelson @emilyaharrington for @natgeo

#everest Route Report: As some of you have seen from my stories, @estebantopomena and I have been preparing gear and nutrition for the route. Many have asked if we are about to go climb, but the honest answer is the winds are high and we are bored. So, to occupy our time, as well as to keep the psych level up, we started preparing what we could. Based on weather, we most likely won‚Äôt be able to get on the new route again for another 2 weeks. Thank you everyone for the well wishes, the prayers, the kind thoughts and the funny notes. It helps us pass the time and makes it all feel a little less lonely.
Regardless of being psyched and excited it still is a mental challenge to battle the internal conversations of loneliness, fear and everything in between. With May being #mentalhealthawarenessmonth, it is important to me to share both the good and the realities that come with climbing this route, not just as an alpinist, but as someone who lives with #bipolar and an advocate for furthering the conversation around #mentalhealth
Pictured here, Topo and I maneuver to the base of the route to stow our gear for when the time is right. Planning and preparations is integral to a successful and safe climb.

#mountains #adventure #climbing #training #mentalhealthawareness
Reclamation in process. Shot #onassignment for #natgeotravel in the Andaman Islands, India.

Photo @estebantopomena 1st attempt: @estebantopomena and I only spent 40 hours on the wall with one open bivvy at 7300 m (around 24,000 ft). The conditions we encountered coupled with our chosen tactics compounded by exertion meant that we had to turn back at around 7,600 m. Downclimbing safely took another 7 hours from our high point. Back in ABC and reassessing our approach, we are looking into the early days of June for a potential second window and attempt. Is it a failure? In the most strict sense of the word, Absolutely. But is it a building block? For sure. I've always maintained that this is truly a journey vs. a summit sport. But to truly understand the whole process, you have to get to the summit. Fingers crossed that happens this season.

Adventure can be experienced in many ways. Culturally, adventure is associated with adrenaline and sports that enduce a thrill. Adventure to me, though, is discovery. It is the peeling back of layers to reveal truth...the truth that is inside me or the truth that surrounds all of us.

In Mustang, Nepal, almost 10 years ago, I was fortunate enough to expienece the merging of the adventure of sport with the adventure of archeological discovery. Maybe I long to be back here over and over because of the lessons I learned, mostly about myself.

Community question: What does 'adventure' mean to you?

Pictured here: An archeologist ascends ropes we fixed to access Neal's 'Sky Caves'. Shot #onassignment for #natgeo.

#discovery #adventure #travel #archeology #nepal #climbing

Shout out to my dear friend and victim (for the shoot), @alexhonnold for putting up with me for the @espn body issue, out today. And a massive thanks to @espn for trusting me with this. //
The first time I photographed Alex Honnold was over a decade ago when our respective cars were our castles, means of transport, and kitchens. I remember the drive from Canada to Yosemite as a jittery sprint fueled by caffeine and gas station cashews. The pictures I took of Alex back then left me wanting, as if there were a depth to his character that was expressed through his action but escaped my ability as a photographer. He struck me as an athlete more sculpted by his medium than any other I‚Äôd met. I wondered if his physical form was a necessary response to repeated stimuli or if he represented something entirely unique. Photographing him all these years later was an opportunity to celebrate him as form born of the stone he surrounds himself with, seeing him as wholly human but somehow simultaneously transcendent of that definition. Plus, it‚Äôs not everyday you get to tell your friend to get naked and curl into a ball and NOT have that abruptly make your friendship forever awkward...
//
Check back for more images from this incredible shoot.

It's easy to convince ourselves that environments have moods...and certainly there are belief systems that would hold to that. I tend to think that we bring our emotions to the mountains...and the mountains themselves are the planet's greatest mirror.

On the day I took this image in 2016, we climbed through snow and cloud. The heat caused by the convection cycle triggered repeated small avalanches that would rumble over seracs obscured by a thick fog on either side. This day, and the mood that I was bringing to it was reminiscent of a not so good day I had in the mountains several years ago when one of the distant rumbles became not so distant and engulfed my partners and I. My neuro-chemistry has never recovered.

That day I was looking in the mirror at a fear that I've never overcome. That day, because I was angry, the mountains were angry. As I climbed the slope beneath the seracs (which are almost as safe as they come), I felt my heart rate increase and my breathing become labored. I was scared, and that made me mad.

But the truth is the mountains are indiscriminate. They don't care. They shine when it is sunny and they fall when it is snowy. It's what we bring to them that defines our experience...and maybe even more important, its how we are changed by them and what we bring home and share that matters most.

I am excited, scared, humbled to experience how the mountains will change me on this new journey through a familiar - yet different - landscape.

Continue to #followme + @ladzinski + @estebantopomena to see our real time stories as we now make our way across the Tibetan plateau from Lhasa to #everest basecamp.
#mentalhealthawareness #climbing #adventure #transformation

Throughout the journey to summit Southeast Asia‚Äôs highest peak, Hkakabo Razi, the team and I passed by many religious sites such as Mingun Pahtodawgi near Mandalay, pictured here.

This site has a fascinating history. These remains are the intentionally unfinished stupa project of King Bbodawpaya. The building of the temple took a tremendous toll on the state and resources and, as a result, a false prophecy was created to slowly stop the project. The prophecy has many iterations since creation, but it generally stated that when the project was complete the king would die. At abandonment, Mingun Pahtodawgi stood only 1/3 of it‚Äôs intended 150 meter height.

King Bodawpaya also had a 90 ton bell cast to accompany the pagoda, and it still, to this day, holds the record of the 2nd largest ringing bell in the world.

Thanks to @stevemccurryofficial for his tireless and beautiful work that has inspired me and so many other photographers. So much of what we create is reimagined images by those who have come before us. For their guidance, I'm eternally indebted.
Shot #onassignment for #NatGeo Magazine‚Äôs article ‚ÄúHow A remote Peak in Myanmar Nearly Broke an Elite Team of Climbers‚Äù

#adventure #travel #culture #burma #myanmar #mingunpahtodawgyi

We just wrapped our final day in Mustang, #nepal. Here are some words about the image I captured above from #NatgGeo #Explorer @jetbutterflies, who helped develop this story and assignment:
.
'A tantric mask rests on an ancient coat of armor in an unnamed ruin near the Tibetan border in Nepal. In Tibetan Buddhism, weapons of war and grotesque figures are used to scare away bad energy and ignorance.

In the isolated Mustang region of Nepal, Buddhist culture is adapting to a number of unexpected changes. The opening of the region to tourism in 1992 sparked an era of prosperity that inspired the revitalization of many ancient monasteries and breathed new life into a shrinking monastic population. Meanwhile, ancient artifacts and valuable religious icons started to go missing and appeared in international collections.'
.
@standtallest @climber.abiral @abovethecloudstrav @sadiequarrier

As many of you who have followed me already know, I have -and will continue to- navigate my challenges with mental health. I have a complicated relationship with social media, and regardless of the bad that comes with this platform, I have experienced the positive that comes with loudly and consistently vocalizing around the topic of Mental Health Awareness. It‚Äôs obvious that images of mountains and climbing get the most likes, BUT anytime I post about a personal struggle with mental health, I receive the most comments, private messages and emails. Veterans, stay-at-home parents, athletes, students, women, men..you name the type of person, I can guarantee they have reached out.
.
I encourage voicing the struggles you may experience if you struggle with Mental Health. You are not in this alone, and it‚Äôs not just about ‚Äúbeing more happy.‚Äù Being vulnerable and vocalizing my challenges was the beginning of finding my individual way through PTSD + Anxiety. It helped me find the right people in my life -the ones that listen, care, empathize and understand. I also encourage anyone and everyone that struggles to find the right professional resources for them. The digital world provides opportunity to find and connect with professionals like never before. .
I also encourage those that might not understand what mental health is to google it, read about it, understand it. For a moment, imagine yourself in the skin of another that battles with mental health. Learn to empathize because I guarantee that if you aren‚Äôt experiencing it, you are surrounded by people that are. .
On this world Mental Health Day, I encourage you to share below your stories, resources and questions. We are already a community here, let‚Äôs use it to our advantage.
.
Pictured here: #Everest expedition 2012, which ended early due to a panic attack.

#mentalhealth #mentalhealthawareness #ptsd #anxiety #bipolar

On the plane to start a new assignment for #natgeo yesterday, I was listening to some podcasts to fill the waiting during travel time, which got me thinking‚Ä¶

I admittedly oscillate between ‚Äúwoo-woo‚Äù and nihilism. Social media can amplify this, especially Instagram. I feel and see community as much as I experience FOMO and isolation. There‚Äôs as much support between the scrolls as there is fear of failure.

I‚Äôm going to err on the side of Woo-woo today and open up a conversation - I know a lot of you are following along more for my stories on #everest than my photojournalism or #mentalhealth awareness - regardless I put in the same energy, effort and exploration whether climbing or telling a story (mine or others). And the process of each of these journeys bring me tremendous joy as well as suffering. Different sides to the same coin.
I was reminded by that podcast, by going for a goal, it brings out aspects of you that wouldn‚Äôt come out otherwise, so when you reach your next ‚Äúmountain top‚Äù, and mountain tops are endless, who‚Äôs with you are the people who are supposed to be with you based on what you have become. So, when you are going for a goal, it‚Äôs not about achieving, it's about who you are becoming on the way of bringing that goal to fruition.
I‚Äôd like to hear your thoughts - what are some journeys you‚Äôve been on that have made you feel the greatest highs and the lowest lows? Does social media inspire you to keep achieving? Or does it just fill the gaps in-between the day? Do you find you have FOMO, how do you deal with it? Does it effect your goals?

#mountains #adventure #exploration #transformation #onassignment

Reading through the comments from yesterday's post, there's a trend that 'optimistic' 'outrage' was a frequent answer to my question: what type of communication activates you towards change?

She frequently uses the concept 'outrage + optimisim' in speaking about climate science. If you're looking to be inspired into action, her twitter account is has some great resources and her TED talk is exceptional, as well. Check her out.

Some people have been asking ‚ÄúWhat is Mustang?‚Äù So: Mustang is a former kingdom in north-central Nepal, and is home to one of the world‚Äôs great archaeological mysteries. Hidden within the Himalaya on walls deeply cleaved by the Kali Gandaki River are an extraordinary number of human-built caves, also known as the 'sky caves.' No one knows who dug them. Or why. Or even how people climbed into them.

I am en route to here, the kingdom of Mustang, for my latest assignment for #natgeo.
Pictured here, daily life against the backdrop of the sky caves - my first published assignment for @natgeo

As some of you have said, we can all do our part in showing up mindfully on this planet, but as the world changes around us, businesses, investors, and financiers have an even larger impact. The finance industry has a responsibility to change the ways they manage economic, environmental and social risks.

Before I settle into Nepal for an upcoming assignment, I am honored to speak at CIMB Investment Bank‚Äôs Cooler Earth Summit in Kuala Lumpur. The summit looks to create action and positive impact while simultaneously showing that businesses can remain relevant and profitable along the way.

#Instagram has been a tremendous platform by which to evoke change and conversation around important topics. Beyond the infinite scroll, I, too, have a responsibility to use this ‚Äúinfluence‚Äù wisely, and am actively engaged directly with brands, political organizations, and financiers as they continue to develop ways to mitigate their impacts.

Are there any specific brands or organizations that you wish to see change the way they do business?

A commitment to climbing mountains means a commitment to failure. Something I am reflecting upon with today being National Mountain Climbing Day.

Ladakh, India. DISCLAIMER: Eyerolling emo deep thoughts to follow. Proceed with caution. // I love portraiture above all forms of photography. We are such an amazing creature. We are both creative and destructive, kind and vicious, powerful and meek, beautiful and ugly. It's my belief however that the majority of us dont live in those binary arenas. Very few people are truly good or bad, black or white...rather, we are infinite shades of grey depending on the day, the hour, the minute...even the second. Thinking of ourselves in binary terms is an attempt at comfort which is an injustice that robs us of our unique complexities. And while I've found that all of us embody a multitude of different shades at any given moment, we are all pretty similar as well. For me, photography has often been a way to seize upon perceived differences in order to expose our overarching similarities as a human family and hopefully bring us closer together. Too see one another completely is to see ourselves, regardless of where we were born, the color of our skin, our gender, what language we speak, or which god we pray to. And while there is unspeakable evil in the world, the power of said darkness pales in comparison to the power we achieve when we see ourselves as a whole and constantly unfolding. Shot #onassignment for #natgeo #portrait #culture #travel #photography #portraitphotography #emo

In 2014, I had the honor to travel on the behalf of #natgeo to Franz Josef Land (FJL), an #arctic Russian archipelago inhabited only by military personnel. Similarly to last post, I witnessed first-hand the changing, melting landscape of pristine land. Since this #expedition, scientific studies have concluded that ‚Äúice mass loss from 2011-2015 has doubled compared to any previous time spans‚Äù. Glacier retreat has been widespread and has led to the creation of at least one new island. Ice wastage, which means the removal of snow or ice from a glacier, was historically relatively small, but accelerating ice loss is the new normal for FJL.

We don‚Äôt need to travel to the arctic to experience our changing environment. There are shifts occurring here in my home of the United States, which some of you have spoken about in yesterday‚Äôs post‚Äôs comment section. To me, this isn‚Äôt a political debate, so let‚Äôs continue the conversation about our experiences and how to personally shift to make better choices - better choices for ourselves and our present *and future* global community.

Pictured here: Walruses approach our expedition boat from a haul out on Hooker Island. During summer, when sea ice diminishes, walruses congregate on shorelines, where food is scarce and youngsters can get trampled.
Shot #onassignment for National Geographic Magazine‚Äôs ‚ÄúFranz Josef Land: The Meaning of North‚Äù

Been on a podcast kick lately and yesterday listened to one about the dichotomy between Belief and Doubt. Believing and doubting are very much two sides of the same coin for me. It follows me through life.. I believe I can accomplish the goals I attempt, yet the journey of exploring this potential success is littered with doubt. Or another example would be: Doubt feeds my discernment on the mountain keeping me safe. At the same time, intense doubt can create stagnation, preventing me from going deeper or trying harder, which as result, could end in final failure.

You all have the floor: Do you believe doubt is essential in having faith? It can be faith in anything. Goals, God, Love‚Ä¶ Tell me the things.

'a lot of you have asked about my skincare routine so here it is:
STEP 1: A triple cleanser by Biophiliac, really good brand, they use soybean extract combined with organic microplastics.
STEP 2: A couple of toners, mainly the set you automatically get in the HP LaserJet Pro M102w Laser Printer G3Q35A.

STEP 3: For eye cream I actually use Simply Organic French Onion Dip Mix just make sure it's the 1.1 oz packet because you're dumb to use a whole jar.

STEP 4: This serum called Gunther's Gums it smells like chocolate, and tastes like it too. Make sure you get the big bottle because you'll go through it fast, especially during dessert.

STEP 5: Depends how I'm feeling, but I either go with a face oil like a soybean cooking oil or a hydrating mask from Elmer's glue and tea tree oil.
STEP 6: Obviously I can't go to bed without my night cream moisturizer, the brand is L'Oxidatione Reservoti Panini Avenatti Overnight Hydrating Facial Moisturizer. I get a tub of it from Lithuania.

hope that helps!' #satire #satiregram #meta #counterculture #skincareroutine #skincare #tutorial #itme

the lil beyonces for my 7-11 video. i went through my old box from 2015 and there's over 500 heads in there that i used just from that year and a lot of others i didn't use. so real talk: i'm 99% certain that right now at this moment i have more lil head cutouts in my possession than any human in all of history. like there's been a lot of people in the world, billions and billions, with a lot of different hobbies and interests and im sure someone at sometime probably had a couple hundred lil cutout heads for some reason but (i probably sounds like i'm boasting) i really don't think any of them have collected more lil head cutouts than me. this just has to be the largest private collection of lil heads ever and i'm probably the #1 human in that category right?? and how neat is that??

the joy of creating ‚Äî sundays with bob part 1 (ft. @martinrussocki) üé®‚ù§Ô∏èüëåüèª #mydaywithbob #bobrossemoji.

there is a lot going on in the world. and you SHOULD absolutely care about that stuff. high on the 'to do list of being a good human' (TM) is caring for your fellow humans and striving to make the world a better place. (high on the 'to do list of being a bad human' (TM) is getting mad at people who are trying to be good humans fyi.) but while you're doing that, dont forget to take time to create, to make things, to perfect the act of doing. that can ALSO help make the world a better place.

this is the first part of a new series where i celebrate the act of doing and honor the legendary bob ross, who spent his life reminding people that anyone can create and creating is fun.

bob once said 'talent is a pursued interest. anything that you're willing to practice, you can do.' i believe that. sometimes young people ask me for advice on how to create. i tell them to just start creating. if you do something every day, even a monkey like me can get good at that thing. i believe my art is proof of that.

over the coming weeks i will keep a bob ross cutout on me at ALL TIMES and keep an eye out for artists in the wild. my first artist in this series is martin russocki who i saw painting in washington square park. his work is really lovely and i like it a lot! i hope you do too.

happy sunday, everybody, enjoy the world around you and don't forget to do something today.

this is one of the very first pictures i took back when i first started playing around with the little cutout technique. id found the image in a book on hollywood hunks and carried it around for a couple days. this photo has always been one of my favorites because burt was always so cool, even wearing teal socks with sandals. hard to pull that off. RIP hollywood hunk.

#mydaywithadayjob part 2 (ft. bey handling a forklift, naturally)

the captions for these will be my musings on the benefits of sidework for creatives.

last week i introduced you to the volunteer bookstore. this week i‚Äôm introducing you to my new job as a forklift operator. kidding. i‚Äôm introducing you to thursdays with ed.

ed is a film historian and author of a bunch of amazing books. he likes a lot of the same movies as me and is pretty mischevious. he‚Äôs in his mid 60s and has parkinson‚Äôs. he gets around okay but struggles with certain motor functions from time to time and going outside can be daunting. parkinson‚Äôs is a nasty disease. he never knows when his legs might lock up, leaving him frozen in a busy manhattan intersection.

my job is basically to help him get to a couple appointments and make sure he doesn‚Äôt fall over. i also consider it part of my job to make sure ed has a nice day on thursdays. i do what i can.

that first day, i didn‚Äôt know what to expect. i‚Äôd never looked after someone with parkinson‚Äôs. (i can barely look after myself!) within 5 minutes right after we shook hands he fell over. it wasn‚Äôt a hard fall: he landed on his bed. his husband showed me the easy way to get him back on his feet (good to know!) but i thought oh great, i‚Äôm gonna be picking this guy up a lot!

now, after a few months, we‚Äôve had a lot of wonderful thursdays. we‚Äôve gone to the movies (the dead don‚Äôt die!), talked about religion in the park, discussed love and regrets and had many belly laughs. and since that first day, ed hasn‚Äôt fallen once!

the other day, ed noted how few ‚Äúepisodes‚Äù he‚Äôd had lately. ‚Äúi hope you‚Äôre not about to fire me‚Äù i said. he replied ‚Äúi‚Äôd make up symptoms to keep you around.‚Äù it‚Äôs nice to feel wanted. and thursdays with ed have put me in a different head space than anything i‚Äôve experienced. i‚Äôm reflective and protective and i love it.

last week, i told ed about my project about the benefits of side work and i asked him if it was okay if i started writing about our thursdays. ‚Äúi could call you fred?‚Äù he said ‚Äúyou better call me ed. and after all the embarrasing things i‚Äôve written about other people, you better embarrass me.‚Äù

the year is 2009.
you just dropped out of college and moved home to start a band.
you are angsty and hungover and trying to figure out your life.
you bleach your hair on a whim using boxed bleach from CVS.
10 years later you‚Äôre waking up in your new home next to your dog. no hangover, no anxiety, your life pretty figured out. still doing that band you dropped out of college to start. growth is tight. and so is getting your hair professionally done.

1 year ago today I woke up with a horrible hangover and tears in my eyes and I told myself, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm done.‚Äù I did a pretty good job of making light of my problem with drugs and alcohol but it eventually reached a point where I knew something had to change. It hasn‚Äôt been easy but oh man has it been rewarding. I‚Äôve never felt more myself than I do today and I owe that to sobriety (and also therapy!) If you‚Äôre struggling, just know there is a way out.

Thank you to all of the people who have been there for me the past year of my life while I went through extreme changes, you know who you are. And to the fans who have been patient with me while I figure out how to navigate said changes- you better believe there‚Äôs plenty of songs that came out of this experience. I‚Äôm beyond grateful to be where I am today because a year ago, it didn‚Äôt seem possible. And not every day is easy, because that‚Äôs life, but every day is a new opportunity to do things differently and that rules. I‚Äôm basically a walking self help book now, so you better get used to it ‚ù§Ô∏èüôèüèª (üì∑ by my precious jewel @juanvigoda)

i‚Äôm 2 years sober today (and still out here partying it up in ridiculous outfits!!!) i‚Äôve never been good at sticking with things, but sobriety has been a journey worth sticking to. big ass love for my life today.

I hope I don‚Äôt come off as an ass... A woman just stopped me in the grocery store and told me that she had never seen a basket like mine.I told her that I have never NOT seen this type of basket in my grocery-shopping behavior.A few others chimed in saying that it was a very strange sight! WTF?A strange sight?I‚Äôm in a grocery store.It‚Äôs food.It got me thinking and really fired up...I hear in the news constantly, in legislative bodies debating and the public complaining out right bitching about healthcare costs, drug companies and doctors and what rising costs do to our society, our lives and our economy. I know our system isn‚Äôt great.Yet, the public poisons itself daily with bad food choices. Food is medicine and medicine is food. It‚Äôs a fact. If we want to see our healthcare system changed, be a healthier society- and it will. How does that sound? Logical right? I don‚Äôt mean to sound like a dick- or preachy but this is nuts: how is it, that grown professional people in a major American city have never seen a grocery basket full of normal&healthy foods that just all happen to be green or not processed.We‚Äôre so far down the rabbit hole of packaged and ‚Äúconvenient‚Äù foods that our society is paying the price&so is our future.No one in our government is helping us be healthier through education.Why would they?Sick people are GREAT for business...
It‚Äôs pretty simple:If you want to look well, feel well and BE well- just eat well. Obviously excersise as well, as much as you can.Everything else will start to fall into place.My mom raised me on no money&mostly as a single parent yet, she still ate well&exercised and it shaped my life.We make excuses why we can‚Äôt find the time to take care of ourselves and we end up past the point of no return... Why is that?How is it that we can‚Äôt see that:Happy and healthy people make a happy and healthy world.It‚Äôs hard to see that through a fog of prescription drugs, energy drinks&strong sleep aids. It‚Äôs hard I know, but its time to change. You wouldn‚Äôt put the wrong gas in your car, so why would you put wrong food in your body? We MUST take responsibility for what we put into our bodies starting now. We can do it.Ok.I‚Äôll stop.Thnks

Unfiltered early morning rides with this guy as the sun rises over the Pacific Ocean. Then some hay for breakfast. The level of beauty and love in these creatures is so vast it‚Äôs out of this world. Even with the immense pressure and stress of building these companies and finishing #VWars this 1200 lb baby boy reminds me to take a breath for me. It‚Äôs hard to do things for ourselves. But we need it. We need our own little rituals for our soul and body to be the best versions of ourselves. Time with a horse is never a waste, even when time is scarce...

Happy #nationalpuppyday from me and this little guy. Puppies are amazing, they remind us to be present and happy. Unfortunately adult humans send their older pets to the shelter to be put down or adopted or put them on Craigslist to make room for puppies around the holidays... It‚Äôs not fair. If you or someone you know have done this or intend to do this please discourage them. Pets are members of our families and do NOT deserve to be abandoned or hrown out for new little ones...

Denise Gutnisky, you are an angel in this world and we all thank you for your tireless effort to bring community together around helping animals, young people and humanity. I adore you and appreciate you- thank you for this. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for all that you do.

Just found this: A season wrap on the Vampire Diaries, maybe Season 3,4or 5 I‚Äôm not sure. I took this in the mirror of Damon‚Äôs dressing room to remember how worn down I was but smiling- That‚Äôs a nebulizer I‚Äôm sucking on-shooting pharmaceutical hydrogen peroxide into my lungs to keep from collapsing from an infection. Supplements, oxygen chambers flying around like a maniac making a TV show and trying to build companies while building @isfofficial . Be careful. Ambition can be dangerous... I‚Äôve found this image and wanted to share it. We‚Äôve lost amazing men and women recently who really helped change the world but their bodies perished from the pressure and abuse of running too hard and not taking care of themselves. I‚Äôm humbly searching for that balance and I wish you all luck in finding it. Meditation helps, I use transcendental mediation or TM- it‚Äôs super easy. Just remember this- we don‚Äôt actually need much to live happy lives. We, as humans firmly believe more and more and more and more ‚Äúthings‚Äù will make us happy. Unfortunately they don‚Äôt make us happy. Our buying patterns just fuels economies ... Our kids deserve to grow up not seeing us staring at these little glowing devices in our hands. I hide around corners and under pillows so my little one doesn‚Äôt see it... Our babies need us present to teach them and to listen to them. It‚Äôs the only way to build a loving and sustainable society. At least that‚Äôs what I think- take it or leave it;)
Cutest hand ever...

As we continue to fight for that more perfect union we all say ‚ÄúThank your Dr. King and family. Your voice still echos, it continues to inspire and your spirit lives on in the heart of every human being who believes in freedom.‚Äù

I‚Äôll never forget the feeling of helplessness watching our communities here in California burn. I‚Äôm grateful that these destructive flames have stopped due to the hard work and risk of the men and women who fought them from the land and from the air. To our FIREFIGHTERS: We are so grateful for you today and everyday. We love and respect you immensely. To all of our Police and other the 1st responders, emergency professionals and volunteers that went in to save people, homes and animals we thank you from the deepest depths of our hearts. We thank each and every one of you to the stars and back. The @losangelesfiredepartment , you are among the greatest heroes on this planet and your bravery and commitment to protecting our state, our people and our creatures is so powerful and so appreciated. Thank you @lafdfoundation for supporting them. From my family to yours, we thank you all on this day. We can only hope that all those affected by natural disasters this year and in recent years find some happiness and a hug today. Hope is all we have to move forward in these terrible moments but together as community we are strong and can share smiles. I send you all love today and applaud your strength and courage to press on. May we start to talk more seriously about where the increasing number of violent hurricanes and fires, that are destroying our homes and communities are coming from and together pave a road to a more peaceful and less destructive future.
Happy Thanksgiving to all and may today not be about gluttonous consumption but gratitude for the simple things in life, the things that we need to survive: Family, friends and food.
With immense gratitude,
Ian Somerhalder
Mondays...

Me at 17 years old.
An America Eagle campaign in the summer of 1996. This was shot in the middle of no where on famous Route 66 at an old desert cafe in the California. How different 1996 was. I read books with an insatiable thirst for philosophy, history, science and nature as shadows lengthened in the sun. What a time. People talked and talked and talked about life on the streets, in parks, in restaurants and bars. It was a special time. The time before the smartphone. I often think about those times when our focus was experiencing moments and not broadcasting every single moment of our entire lives... there was so much clarity. I miss those times...

I have just been quietly off of social media mourning the loss of so much life on our planet happening around us. We are the same biological process as the planet. What we do to our world we do ourselves. The trees are the Earth‚Äôs lungs, oceans and rivers act as the world‚Äôs cardiovascular system carrying all of the vital nutrients to the world‚Äôs organs (the very things that give us life) The unnecessary and illegal man-made fires ripping through the Amazon (the vital lungs of our planet), Hurricane Dorian ripping through the Beautiful Bahamas and the South East on a path of destruction. Now Japan is telling us that they may have to dump enormous amounts of radioactive waste water into the ocean because they are running out of space to store it. Where DOES it end? I can‚Äôt be silent any longer... WE MUST stop the destruction and senseless slaughter of all that gives us life: RAIN FORESTS AND OCEANS. We can not afford to lose one more acre of forest, we can‚Äôt take any more storms and radioactive waste. HOW DO WE DO THIS? SOMEONE? #Repost @paulnicklen with @get_repost

The latest instalment of @biekedepoorter's long-running project, 'Agata', is going on show at @parisphotofair this week as part of the @huaweinextimage Awards stand.
.
The project started in November 2017, as a result of Magnum‚Äôs Live Lab in Paris. While in the French capital Depoorter was invited to visit an infamous strip club in the Pigalle district where she met Agata, a young dancer working at the club. Agata invited Depoorter back to her home and together they made the very first photographs in what was to become a years-long project. .
Earlier this year the pair travelled to Lebanon to continue the work, with the support of the @huaweinextimage Awards.
.
You can see the work on show at the NEXT-IMAGE Awards stands at Paris Photo from November 7 to 10. At the stand, @huawei will also be exhibiting the winning submissions from this year‚Äôs 520,000 entries.
.
For more information, please visit magnumphotos.com/events.
.

.

.

‚ÄúMy life as a photographer has consisted of many travels across the African continent, a land impregnated with unusual, peculiar things, where unexpected moments can happen.
.
This picture was taken late one night in Brazzaville, Congo, in a neighborhood restaurant in the Poto-Poto district. It was taken with my Leica, after a hard day of work, almost without my knowledge.
.
A shadow like that of a Chinese (or should I say African?) puppet, lends itself to the game. Solicited by this ephemeral shadow, the wall agrees to participate. It proposes and positions the eye and the eyebrow to reveal this fugitive, invented profile, by capturing these shadows, framed by arms.
.
A photograph passes from one hand to another, a souvenir exchanged‚Ä¶
.
It was Sunday, October 27, 1985.‚Äù - Guy Le Querrec
.
PHOTO: Poto-Poto, Brazzaville, Congo. Sunday, October 27, 1985.
.

.

For more than a year in the late 1960s Magnum photographer Dennis Stock and writer William Hedgepeth roved across America exploring the nation‚Äôs new commune culture ‚Äì from the urban countercultural meccas of Haight Ashbury and the East Village, to isolated ranches, desert retreats, and wooded campsites.
.

'This image, dating from 1976, was part of Erich Hartmann‚Äôs experimental efforts to incorporate into his pictures another dimension, Time, here presented as Motion. .
In the seemingly limitless space pictured‚Äìin reality the great hall of Grand Central Station‚Äìone woman stands still and apart in the foreground; perfectly placed at a middle distance is a package-carrying male figure. Beyond them is a moving mass of people and their shadows almost melded together, each person a specific part of a whole, but hidden in anonymity from one another.'- Erich Hartmann
.

There are less than two days left only to buy this print from @raghurai.official in The Magnum Square Print Sale in Partnership with @aperturefnd! Shop the sale via the link in bio.
.
‚ÄúI was shooting in Mumbai city for a book project in 1996. I had heard of local trains arriving into the city with a human deluge that was unmeasurable, a flood of people who would then be dispersed to their places of work. Sure enough, I reached Churchgate railway station‚Äìthe busiest place in the heart of the city‚Äìat 8 a.m. I stood there in awe and amazement, with an unimaginable and overpowering feeling of the deluge. It took less than a minute for thousands of commuters to disappear. The platform was empty again until 3 or 4 minutes later, when more trains arrived to bring in another deluge. .
More than the crowds, I wanted to capture so many human bodies melting into each other and disappearing in a mad rush to get to their respective places of work. So I put my camera on a 5 foot-high switch box almost in the middle of the space between two tracks and exposed it at one-eighth of a second in order to capture the deluge. But those sitting on the benches reading the morning newspaper or waiting for someone remained still. This expression is visible anytime of the day in most metropolitan cities in India.‚Äù- @raghurai.official
.
PHOTO: Local commuters at Churchgate railway station. Mumbai, India. 1995.
.
¬© @raghurai.official/#MagnumPhotos
.
#MAGNUMSQUARE #Hidden #India #Mumbai #streetphotography #RaghuRai

From dancers in China, to 'Gauchos' in Chile and patients with dementia in The Netherlands, 21 Magnum photographers were commissioned to capture the myriad stories of older persons around the world for @AARP, drawing on the lives of extraordinary individuals as well as upon everyday stories. .

@martinparrstudio selects an early black and white image from his work in Hebden Bridge, Yorkshire for the Magnum Square Print Sale in Partnership with @aperturefnd. This is a rare chance to buy a signed Martin Parr print for only $100! Link in bio. ‚ÄúThis is the Ancient Order of Henpecked Husbands, a secret society meeting on Easter Monday. They used to meet in Hebden Bridge in the late 70s, when I lived there. The idea was that it would mock the freemasons and also be a club where husbands could chat amongst themselves, without being interrupted by their wives.
.

Micha Bar-Am shares the story behind this unusual family portrait. The signed print is available this week only! Link in bio.
.
‚ÄúIn 1991, Iraq attacked Israel with Scud missiles over the course of six weeks. Israel, for the first time ever, refrained from retaliating, bowing to pressure from the United States, which was leading an offensive against Iraq. Because the missiles were capable of carrying chemical or biological warheads, Israelis were equipped with gas masks and instructed to seal off a room in their homes. Oddly, there was no solution for bearded men like myself, nor for pets, who could not wear the masks.
.
The day on which the first missile was launched the siren sounded and everybody gathered in the sealed room. I was ready to photograph it, with my equipment already in my car, when I heard the alarm, but as it was not clear yet whether the missile was ‚Äòconventional‚Äô or not, I decided to wait it out with my family‚Äìmy wife, our two sons, and our house cat. So I photographed them.
.
As it turned out, the warheads did not contain unconventional materials but the damage that the 39 missiles caused was severe. Most of them landed not far from our home and we could hear every explosion. By the way, today there is free distribution of special masks for bearded people and a special solution for pets.‚Äù- Micha Bar-Am
.
PHOTO: Family Portrait with Cat, Gulf War. Ramat Gan, Israel. 1991.
.
¬© #MichaBarAm/#MagnumPhotos
.

‚ÄúI was in Marrakech in 1986 during the Folklore Festival. Sitting on a dirt wall, there was a group of girls waiting to perform. As soon as they saw me taking pictures, they started hiding, covering their faces with their hands, then uncovering them slightly to look at me, then covering them again. It was like a game of seduction and, though they were quite young, they already seemed to know that to hide and to show were the basic rules of the game. They kept playing at it for a little while, laughing loudly. It would have been great to have the soundtrack with this image.‚Äù- Harry Gruyaert

'In 2017, while working on an exhibition commission on nuclear weapons for the Nobel Peace Prize, I applied for permission to visit the vast Nevada Air Force Base Complex‚Äìwhich is known for its lunar landscape, a result of all the nuclear weapons tests carried out there‚Äìbut we were turned down. I was forced to be ‚Äòoutside looking in,‚Äô driving along its perimeter and trying to metaphorically see what was hidden beyond those mountains. For the exhibition commission, I created a series of diptychs comparing American Cold War-era nuclear landscapes with present-day North Korean ones. Indeed, I was also kept out of the North Korean plants, and had to photograph from the Chinese side of their shared border, at the closest points to Pyongyang‚Äôs known nuclear and military sites.
.
In a similar way to other landscape imagery in my practice, the photograph‚Äìoften taken to be, by nature, evidential‚Äìis almost counter-evidential in this case. Nothing is laid out in plain sight. These landscapes can be read with some imagination, to ‚Äòsee‚Äô what lies beneath, beyond.' - @chiyin_sim

‚ÄúThis charming photo shows legendary fashion photographer Richard Avedon and Hollywood superstar dancer Fred Astaire. They are both hiding from the rain and behind a large-format camera with playful smiles and practiced poses, all captured by Magnum‚Äôs co-founder, David ‚ÄòChim‚Äô Seymour. The three men were in Paris with Audrey Hepburn for the making of the film Funny Face, which earned four Academy Award nominations.
.
Avedon‚Äôs obituary in the The New York Times states that his ‚Äòfashion and portrait photographs helped define America's image of style, beauty and culture for the last half-century.‚Äô Astaire‚Äôs obituary noted that his ‚Äòflashing feet and limber legs not only made him America's most popular dancer but also set standards for motion picture musical comedies that have rarely been met and never exceeded.‚Äô
.
Photographers often hide behind their cameras, but rarely do they allow themselves to be photographed in their secretive mode of work. Chim‚Äôs personal engagement with these two fabled stars enabled him to record this delightful encounter, which mocks the idea of hiding behind a camera.‚Äù- Ben Shneiderman, David Seymour‚Äôs nephew (www.davidseymour.com)

Ending soon! @christopherandersonphoto responds to the theme of 'Hidden' with an image and personal text. You can buy the signed print for $100 on shop.magnumphotos.com today only. Link in bio.

‚ÄúIn the years following September 11, 2001, I made many trips to Afghanistan. It is a place where much seems hidden.
.
I made this photograph in 2004. These guys were cleaning carpets by shaking out the dust. A Sisyphean task. Dust is one of the things about Afghanistan that I still remember in a visceral way. It was more like beige, talcum powder than dust, seeping into every crack and seam. I imagined that it must be like the dust on the moon (which is where going to Afghanistan felt like at the time). Thousands of years of dry, chalky rock, ground up underfoot until it did not even qualify as sand. .
And it destroyed cameras. At the time, I used Fuji 645 film cameras that had plastic gears in the internal workings. The dust would grind the teeth off the gears. My cameras had to be practically rebuilt after each trip. It became more costly to fix the cameras than to just get new ones.‚Äù - @oh_anderson/Magnum Photos
.
PHOTO: Men shake dust from rugs that were used for a wedding party. Kabul, Afghanistan. 2004.
.
¬© @christopherandersonphoto/Magnum Photos
.
#MAGNUMSQUARE #Hidden #ChristopherAnderson

'The Walls is the oldest unit in the Texas prison, opened in 1849. Beginning in 1982, 562 men have died in its execution chambers. I spent most of 1968 walking around inside the Walls. I used the prints I was making for Conversations with the Dead , most of them in Bruce Davidson‚Äôs darkroom on W. 86th street, to apply for a Guggenheim Fellowship. Afterward the foundation asked if they could have one of the prints. It was The Dominoes Players. In the 1990s, Magnum sent that roll of negatives to a printer for an enlargement and for some reason the printer cut the frame off from the strip of six, frame 36, the last image on the roll. Another decade went by and Magnum decided my original cellulose negative sleeves were not archival so all the prison negatives were moved from the original sleeves into archival paper sleeves. Only the person doing this neglected to look inside the originals for a single separated frame. The old sleeves were burned in the garbage and that was the end of the negative of one of the best pictures I would ever make. I had a single surviving vintage print, and with the arrival of the digital age, it was scanned allowing these small prints to be made. ' - @dannylyonphotos
.
PHOTO: The Dominoes Players. Walls Unit, Huntsville, Texas, USA. 1968. .
¬© @dannylyonphotos/#MagnumPhotos
.

‚ÄúThe Kayan Lahwi people live in the state of Kayah in Myanmar. They are farmers and Buddhists. The Kayan Lahwi women traditionally wear brass rings around their necks. I don't know when this strange custom began. Tourists, Thai or foreign, call these women ‚ÄòLong Neck‚Äô or ‚ÄòGiraffe‚Äô ladies.
.
A small area has been set up for tourists, who have to pay fees to enter. Most of these fees, I fear, go directly to the officials. Back in the 1930s, Englishmen took several ‚ÄòLong Neck‚Äô women to London to show them at a circus. Indeed, when I took a group tour there once, I was horrified to see tourists acting as though they were visiting a circus, a zoo even. .
I went back there alone twice in the early morning. It was then that I could see a piece of their normal, daily life.‚Äù - Hiroji Kubota
.

2019 Magnum nominee @nannaheitmann selects an image from her series 'Hiding from Baba Yaga' for the Magnum Square Print Sale in Partnership with @aperturefnd. Heitmann's signed print is available via the link in bio.
.
‚ÄúFrom time immemorial people have sought protection and freedom on the banks of the Yenisei River, whose stream I followed. My journey took me to Tyva Republic, where the Yenisei starts its journey. Arriving in Tyva in southern Siberia left a vivid mark on my memory. On the drive there, as you climb higher and higher, you cross endless forests and mountains. People I passed on the way warned me that although Tyva belongs to Russia it is like the Wild West. Suddenly, as I crossed the mountains, the forests ended, and the land opened out in front of me. I was engulfed by heat. I had entered the Tyva Republic: It felt like entering a different world. .
On the day this picture was taken, a horse race was taking place. It was 43 degrees celsius and the boys had to race 30 km. The young rider shook off the rest of the group. For one moment it felt as though he was riding in the middle of the steppe alone, all by himself.‚Äù - @nannaheitmann
.

The Second Battle of Fallujah started on November 7, 2004, and lasted one and a half months ‚Äì ending just before Christmas Eve. The US-led effort against insurgents in the city was code-named Operation Phantom Fury, and marked the first instance of Coalition military action against a purely insurgent force, since the toppling of the Ba-athist government in 2003.

The fighting in the city has since been recognized by many as the most intense urban warfare since the battle of Hu·∫ø city during the Vietnam War. @jeromesessini was in Fallujah embedded with US Marines of Charlie Company, at work in the north eastern sector of the city for one week.

‚ÄúI made this photograph in the 1980s while on assignment in South Carolina for People magazine. While my subject was being taken care of in the barber‚Äôs chair, I made this photograph of a young boy who brought to mind memories of black-owned barbershops.
.
Since I was young, I have always felt that spending time in a black barbershop was equivalent to attending church. Each visit was a shared ritualistic experience among the male clients. Everything was discussed; everyone in the shop was close to the action. It was a place of shared mysteries where grown men spoke amongst themselves, sharing life experiences with young boys in a casual way. Magnum photographer @oliviarthur reflects on the notion of being 'Hidden' in Saudi Arabia. Arthur's signed print is available until Friday via the link in bio. .
‚ÄúThe notion of being hidden is pretty well established in Saudi Arabia: most obviously, women inside their abayas and niqabs, but also families behind the high walls of their houses, and young men and women who are separated from each other in public spaces. But the concept of what is hidden also depends on who is looking. Being hidden from one‚Äôs family or from the religious police might also mean being hidden from the rules, and subsequently enjoying the chance to be more liberal.
.
This image was taken in Durrat Al-Arous, a beach town just outside Jeddah where families and young people come on the weekend to relax. Because it is privately owned, the rules of Saudi society don‚Äôt apply and young people can hang out together, wear what they like; women can drive cars or ride bikes. So in a way people are hidden from the rule-makers, and that allows them to be less hidden from one another.‚Äù - @oliviarthur
.
PHOTO: A girl sunbathes in the private beach town of Durrat Al-Arous, where the rules of Saudi society are not enforced. Durrat Al-Arous, Saudi Arabia. 2009.
.
¬© @oliviarthur/#MagnumPhotos
.
#MAGNUMSQUARE #Hidden

The Man in Black ‚ö°Ô∏è
Like most kids growing up, I dreamed about being a superhero. Having cool superpowers, fighting for what‚Äôs right and always protecting the people.
It all changed for me, when I was 10yrs old and was first introduced to the greatest superhero of all time - SUPERMAN.
As a kid, Superman was the hero I always wanted to be.
But, a few years into my fantasy, I realized that Superman was the hero, I could never be.
I was too rebellious. Too rambunctious. Too resistant to convention and authority.
Despite my troubles, I was still a good kid with a good heart - I just liked to do things my way.
Now, years later as a man, with the same DNA I had as a kid - my superhero dreams have come true.
I‚Äôm honored to join the iconic #DCUniverse and it‚Äôs a true pleasure to become, BLACK ADAM.
BLACK ADAM is blessed by magic with the powers equal to SUPERMAN, but the difference is he doesn‚Äôt toe the mark or walk the line.
He‚Äôs a rebellious, one of a kind superhero, who‚Äôll always do what‚Äôs right for the people - but he does it his way.
Truth and justice - the BLACK ADAM way.
This role is unlike any other I‚Äôve ever played in my career and I‚Äôm grateful to the bone we‚Äôll all go on this journey together.
BLACK ADAM

Cool Univ of Miami football throwback üèà
1993 Sugar Bowl in New Orleans.
Me and my teammate and workout buddy, Bruce Eberst - big dude wearing the üß¢ lid.
We rolled into New Orleans undefeated and the #1 team in the country - playing the #2 team, Univ of Alabama for the NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP.
We lost 34-13.
Tough loss. Learned a lot.
I was banged up most of my college career (shoulder reconstruction, three knee surgeries and blew my back out with two total ruptures of my discs) but man these years were formidable and defining.
Made some good friends and we took pride in being the hardest workers in the country.
Thanks to my guy and our Heisman Trophy winner, @ginotorretta13 for posting this‚òùüèæone.
What a long, winding road life can be.

PEBBLE PEOPLE:

Something wonderful was told to me just recently. Two scientists who were researching the effect of waves in the ocean for two years, came to the conclusion that the smallest stimulus to the water be it a drop of a pebble, or a child splashing the water at the shore, affects the whole ocean, each time. Well, I thought we do affect each other on land, but I hadn‚Äôt realized that that was true in the ocean as well! What a blessing!
So now I call ourselves the small pebble people. Send small pebbles to the world. Don‚Äôt make big splashes with large stones. That will attract people and the wrong people as well. Our quiet revolution will not make announcements, but one day will be accepted by all people as the norm of life. The human race has done that with many things. This time, we want to heal our planet, and bring peace to this world. We will. Love, yoko

I was fearing the day when I take a look at new jersey like this and it will be lined with high rises. Now it‚Äôs a bit sparse still. You see the river is totally frozen - with the waves still making the mark! New York my love, you are beautiful every day! Even in this weather when everything around us is frozen except my heart... My heart is jumping for no reason.. My voice which was husky since my birthday, is clear again. I wonder if spring is coming sooner than we thought?

The show was conceptual from begining to end. Notice I am carrying F to make it Museum of Modern Fart! Well, That‚Äôs the kind of gal I was and probably still. The very sensitive curators of MOMA today picked up on this, and decided to give me a real Show at MOMA‚Ä¶to realize this conceptual show. I am flabbergasted that the curators of MOMA noticed what I did in 1971 = 44 years ago! So I decided to go along with them and do this show in MOMA this year‚Ä¶opening of which is this coming May 17th. Because what was just a conceptual dream of mine - though it was expressed pretty elaboratedly at the time with a catalogue and an advertisement in the Village Voice (as follows) I never thought it can become a reality forty years or so later. I wanted to show my dear friends who are cynical about such a thing how mysterious life is. And things can work as long as you make the wish, no matter how small the wish was expressed and presented.
Of course, even I did not believe that this will happen. I just said ‚ÄòNEXT!‚Äù and moved on at the time. This is the first TIME PEACE, I created inadvertently! I created two more TIME PEACE this year. Big hug to all of you! yoko
Change is not always bad. I love you! yoko

Life is beautiful. yoko

This is in the new Whitney Museum! I went there for the first time today and almost choked up. I saw the sky I love from so many windows and terraces. But that was not the important surprise. Inside were the paintings of familiar artists we have never seen before. I can say ‚Äúwe‚Äù because none of us saw these particular paintings which were in the basement of the old Whitney up to now.
I‚Äôm glad they are aired finally. It shows how great the American artists has been, especially the women artists. We have to quickly change our minds about the art history we vaguely had in our minds. I say vaguely because this important witness to American Art were never out in the open until now.
Whitney is now quickly rearranging our mind computer to very, very beautiful and important truth - especially for the kids of America‚Ä¶ I love you! yoko
What is a reality anyway, unless we make it happen... yoko

DAVID BOWIE
John and David respected each other. They were well matched in intellect and talent. As John and I had very few friends we felt David was as close as family.

After John died, David was always there for Sean and me. When Sean was at boarding school in Switzerland, David would pick him up and take him on trips to museums and let Sean hang out at his recording studio in Geneva.

For Sean this is losing another father figure. It will be hard for him, I know. But we have some sweet memories which will stay with us forever.

Yoko Ono Lennon
NYC, 11 January 2016

I decided to do a book on India because I had been there several times and even though it was everything I had expected it was even more rich and diverse than anything I had seen in books or magazines. I wanted to capture the India I was experiencing which was a beautiful mix of rural and city, youth culture, sports, food and amazing landscapes! This book certainly isn‚Äôt an encyclopedic tour of the country but more visual journal. Thanks @taschen , Reuel Golden for editing and @behavebandana for writing an amazing introduction

Repost from @barackobama on Toni Morrison‚Äôs passing. :
Time is no match for Toni Morrison. In her writing, she sometimes toyed with it, warping and creasing it, bending it to her masterful will. In her life‚Äôs story, too, she treated time nontraditionally. A child of the Great Migration who‚Äôd lifted up new, more diverse voices in American literature as an editor, Toni didn‚Äôt publish her first novel until she was 39 years old. From there followed an ascendant career‚Äîa Pulitzer, a Nobel, and so much more‚Äîand with it, a fusion of the African American story within the American story. Toni Morrison was a national treasure. Her writing was not just beautiful but meaningful‚Äîa challenge to our conscience and a call to greater empathy. She was as good a storyteller, as captivating, in person as she was on the page. And so even as Michelle and I mourn her loss and send our warmest sympathies to her family and friends, we know that her stories‚Äîthat our stories‚Äîwill always be with us, and with those who come after, and on and on, for all time.

Art and post via artist, activist, @giffordscourage fellow, and high school student @gracieleeart .
üó£
‚ÄúThis is America‚Äù PART THREE. Please see the artist‚Äôs feed (@gracieleeart) for parts one and two. üó£
I‚Äôm doing this series of drawings because I know that art has the power to change minds. Young people have the power to change minds. I know this first hand. I‚Äôve been working on this series all day for 3 days. Do I want to be doing this? No. I really wish I didn‚Äôt have to but I do. There have been so many shootings in places all over this country that it would take weeks to draw them all. As I‚Äôm drawing I‚Äôm thinking of all the people and families whose lives have been destroyed by gun violence. I have met many of them. I‚Äôm thinking about the innocent children in Sandy Hook. I‚Äôm thinking of the grandparents murdered in the synagogue. I‚Äôm thinking of the dozens of people in Chicago that were shot this weekend but didn‚Äôt even make the news. I‚Äôm seeing stories of families in El Paso and Dayton who are still in a state of shock. We‚Äôve had enough and we‚Äôve made that very clear. But nothing ever changes. So I ask you again to listen to the majority of Americans who are urging you to call an emergency session in the senate to allow for a vote on universal background checks. The time is now and every day you wait makes us one step closer to another tragedy. #endgunviolence #enoughisenough #enough #neveragain #gunviolence #gunsense #gunreformnow #backgroundchecks #wheresmitch #emergencysession
